tossups.question: One politician ran for this office after losing his medical license due to his insistent claim that the implantation of “goat glands” would restore human fertility; he then ran a second time for this office, voicing his views on a Mexican border blasting AM radio station. Starting in 1879, this office was held by the Prohibition Party candidate John St. John. The future Secretary of War Harry Woodring ascended to this office by defeating the aforementioned quack doctor John R. Brinkley. A Time Magazine reporter joked that “considerable mystery surrounds the disappearance” of the most illustrious man to hold this office, since he did not travel during his presidential run. That man’s landslide defeat in his run for president led to another quip, “As Maine goes, so goes Vermont,” since those were the only states he carried in 1936. For 10 points, name this highest office held by Alf Landon.

A character in this novel responds to the Good Friday prohibition on plums by calling a god that would care about food “strange”, and claiming that her god is over the bed of Mrs. Samuel Boor. At novel’s opening, the narrator describes how “this book is not written for God” but rather for other people. This novel centers on a woman whose mother committed suicide after her twin siblings were killed by lightning. Its narrator believes that a woman stole all the furniture from a Jewish family before learning that she sheltered their baby Eva Grossman during the Holocaust. In this novel, a woman insists on naming a dog Viola even though the dog is male. This novel opens and closes with the narrator’s dream that she is unable to allow paramedics to save a patient, paralleling her attempts to save her housekeeper. For 10 points, name this novel about the mysterious Emerence, written by Magda Szabo (SAH-boh).

A ballet by this man takes place on a boat making a trans-Atlantic journey, and features himself, George Bernard Shaw, and Gertrude Stein as characters. In another of his works, Sarah is persuaded to marry the Marquis of Shayne after her true love, the musician Carl, is killed in a duel; in that work, Manon sings a song stating “I believe in doing what I can / in crying when I must.” This composer of The Grand Tour wrote a ditty claiming the title group “are effete / they’re quite impervious to heat” and that they “detest a siesta.” This composer’s operetta Bitter Sweet included the songs “If Love Were All” and the waltz “I’ll See You Again.” His best-known song describes a time of day “in tropical climes” “when all the citizens retire to tear their clothes off and perspire.” For 10 points, name this flamboyant Brit who wrote and sang “Mad Dogs and Englishmen go out in the midday sun.”

The likelihood of response to these things is quantified using a “summarizing” equation with terms like “s-H-r” and “s-L-r”. Leopold Szondi proposed that these things are made up of two opposing components in his namesake “diagrams” of them. An early experiment that tested a theory of these things made use of numerous cockroaches running in a maze. Robert Zajonc (ZYE-ents) theorized that due to these things, people perform better at easy tasks when being observed, but worse at hard ones, as an example of the social facilitation effect. The primary types of these things are essential for survival unlike secondary ones. Clark Hull theorized that motivation was caused by a desire for “reduction” of these things. Two of these states, Eros and Thanatos, were proposed by Sigmund Freud. For 10 points, name these excited psychological states created by some sort of need, such as thirst.

It’s not a class, but a puzzle about the phylogeny of this clade partially hinges on the lack of genetic information on the genus Sphenodon. In members of this clade, the pronephros and mesonephros appear during embryonic development, but the metanephros is the final adult kidney. Unlike ancestors which used buccal pumping, this clade evolved costal respiration. They generally possess at least two pairs of sacral ribs. This clade first appeared in the Carboniferous, and they later diverged into Anapsids, Diapsids, and Synapsids. This clade’s characteristic structure contains the allantois and chorion, which allows for gas exchange. Their eggs generally adapted to have hard shells to be better suited to life on land. For 10 points, name this clade which includes birds, reptiles, and mammals and whose name derives from a membrane in their eggs which encases the embryo and a certain “fluid”.
tossups.answer: amniotes [prompt on tetrapods; accept diapsids until mention; prompt afterwards]
tossups.answer_formatted: amniotes [prompt on tetrapods; accept diapsids until mention; prompt afterwards]

tossups.question: At one point this text describes the "urination of huge children [who] stood loosely military." The last of its four paragraphs begins by describing how "my mother, my father, my uncle, my aunt and I too lie there" before concluding that none of them will tell the narrator who he is. This work's author said he wrote it in 90 minutes as "a kind of parallel to improvisation in jazz." First published in the Partisan Review, it includes a passage describing how various water pressures in hoses tune them like violins before noting "there is never one locust but the illusion of at least a thousand." The narrator says he is "successfully disguised to himself as a child," before describing "that time of evening when people sit on their porches." It became the opening to a novel centering on the aftermath of Rufus Follett’s death. For 10 points, name this James Agee piece which was set to music by Samuel Barber.

One of these philosophers examined the statements “you know that a king is seated” to ask if it is possible to “know that a king is seated” by “not knowing that he is not seated”. That one of these philosophers suggested Plato could be whiter than Socrates in a book titled for statements that can be both true and false, Sophismata. Another of these philosophers, who was once archbishop of Canterbury, proved that an accelerating body starting at rest will travel the same distance as a body travelling at a constant speed equal to half its max velocity. These philosophers included William Heytesbury and Richard Kilvington, and they take one of their alternate names from Merton College. Thomas Bradwardine, who proved the mean speed theorem, was a leader of, for 10 points, what 14th-century philosophers who solved theological problems using logic at a namesake English university?
tossups.answer: Oxford Calculators [prompt on Oxford School; accept Merton School before “Merton”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Oxford Calculators [prompt on Oxford School; accept Merton School before “Merton”]

tossups.question: This ruler legendarily saved the Karaites, whom he had resettled in his capital, from a flood by ordering his horse to drink the floodwaters. This ruler’s attempt to restore Tokhtamysh to power as khan of the Golden Horde resulted in his defeat by Temür Qutlugh and Edigü at the Battle of the Vorskla River. This ruler recovered his father’s lands, and finished his father’s construction of the Trakai Island Castle after reconciling with his cousin through the Astrava Agreement. After being offered the crown of Bohemia, this ruler sent his nephew Sigismund Korybut to Bohemia as governor. The death of this son of Keştutis led to a civil war between supporters of his brother Sigismund and his cousin Švitrigaila. For 10 points, name this Grand Duke of Lithuania known as “the Great,” who defeated the Teutonic Order alongside his cousin Jogaila at the Battle of Grunwald.
tossups.answer: Vytautas the Great [or Vytautas Didysis or Witold Kiejstutowicz]

tossups.question: A painting by this artist was going to be auctioned by its owner, the company Diageo (DIE-uh-JEE-oh), but a fundraising drive secured it for the National Galleries. Faeries ride big-ass rabbits, and Titania hugs Nick Bottom in this artist’s Scene from A Midsummer Night’s Dream. This artist painted a monarch dressed in black sitting on a black pony as a tribute to the sadness the monarch experienced upon the death of her husband. A telescope lies in the snow and a polar bear gnaws on a human rib in this artist’s Man Proposes, God Disposes. A black doggie proffers a letter to a poodle that rests his paws on an open book in this man’s painting Laying Down the Law. His most famous painting has been used to market whiskey, and depicts a stag standing in front of mountains. For 10 points, name this kitschy painter of Monarch of the Glen, who is better known for his lion sculptures at Trafalgar Square.
tossups.answer: Sir Edwin Landseer [or Edwin Henry Landseer]

tossups.question: Nika et al. calculated this quantity's value for graphene in terms of the Gruneisen parameters for LA and TA modes using the Klemens approximation. This quantity equals pi squared over 3 times the ratio of Boltzmann's constant to the fundamental charge squared times temperature times electric conductivity according to the Wiedeman-Franz law. This quantity would be infinite in a perfectly harmonic crystal. At high temperatures, this quantity falls off as one over temperature, since umklapp processes become dominant, decreasing the phonon mean free path. Flame ionization detectors and devices which measure this quantity are the most common detector types used in gas chromatography. This quantity is found in the denominator of the Nusselt number. For 10 points, name this quantity, which multiplies minus the temperature gradient to give the heat flux in Fourier's law.

In this country, a politician and religious leader declared in a speech that “there is not a square inch in the whole domain of our human existence over which Christ” “does not cry, ‘Mine!’” That speech delivered at the 1880 inauguration of the Free University compared social spheres to cogwheels and formulated the doctrine of “Sphere Sovereignty.” The man who gave that speech was the founder of this country’s Anti-Revolutionary Party and leader of the Doleantie movement. An agreement called the Pacification of 1917 ended the “school struggle” in this country by guaranteeing state funding of parochial schools, contributing to “pillarization,” a system in which Protestants, Catholics, and socialists in this country set up separate societal institutions. For 10 points, name this country where the Calvinist theologian Abraham Kuyper served as prime minister under its queen Wilhelmina.

In one essay, this writer claimed that “shadow beasts” or “desconociementos,” such as numbness and anger, stalked her after the Twin Towers fell. That essay compares writing to healing a fragmented identity and is part of this writer’s directive named for a goddess who was beheaded. In her most famous book, this author imagines confronting an underworld goddess and licking her icy face as analogous to confronting herself using a mirror. This theorizer of the “Coyolxauhqui (KOH-yoll-SHOU-kwee) imperative”, may be best known for a book that code switches between English and Spanish, and discusses “The Coatlicue State” before concluding with the assertion “This land was Mexican once / was Indian always / and is. And will be again.” The “mestiza consciousness”, was introduced in Borderlands, a book by, for 10 points, what lesbian Chicana author?

In 4D examples of these theories, Komargodski and Schwimmer proved the existence of a function which decreases monotonically under RNG flow; but the status of that “A-theorem” is unknown in six dimensions. The “data” of these theories is used as input to a technique that uses crossing symmetry to fix four-point functions of their primary operators; that’s their “bootstrap” technique. The Weyl anomaly is a violation of the key symmetry of this class of theories, which also describes the worldsheet of string theory. 2D examples of these theories have infinite-dimensional symmetry groups generated by Virasoro algebras. Statistical systems at their critical point can be described by these theories since the divergence of the correlation length leads to these theories' characteristic scale invariance. For 10 points, what type of QFT was conjectured by Juan Maldacena to be dual to gravitational theories in anti-de Sitter space?

The first mention of this food in writing is a cuneiform tablet by Yaqqim-Addu, in which he laments that his Amorite lord does not like them. Though it is not a potato, examples of this food of genus Tuber are used to make Black Moth Vodka. Using animal saliva, the chemist Vladimir Prelog first isolated androstenol, a compound found in some varieties of this non-animal food. 2-4 Di∙thia∙pentane is often used as an aromatic in this food’s namesake “oil”, which is actually made using olives in its stead. This food’s varieties include the Black Perigord, as well as the white d’Alba Madonna, the latter of which often sells for about 1-2 thousand dollars per pound. Brillat-Savarin wrote that this food cannot be cultivated, which is why female dogs and other animals are trained to hunt it out. For 10 points, name this expensive fruiting body of a fungus, which are hunted using pigs.

In a chapter called “Myths in the Forms of Klein’s Bottle,” Claude Levi-Strauss recounts a Tumupasa myth in which this animal has three testicles and a giant penis because this animal copulated with its wife before she could eat the Moon. A goddess who rides this non-jaguar and non-lion animal forms a trinity with Guaicaipuro and Negro Felipe, and is served by both Jesus and Simon Bolivar. The Haptodon fossil is thought to be a predecessor to this animal, which is the mount for the Venezuelan goddess Maria Lionza. The kabomani species of it was supposedly first identified during an expedition by Teddy Roosevelt. Though there exists “Malayan” and “mountain” forms of this ungulate, the more common South American form of this animal is named after Spencer Baird. A Portuguese word for “thick” gives its name to, and describes the nose of, for 10 points, what mammal with a prehensile snout?

John Thompson called those engaged in this project “the intellectual confreres of Linnaeus” wondering if “a future Darwin will conceptualize and unify” their work. Though it was announced as complete by Gorenstein in 1983, it wasn’t actually finished until Aschbacher and Smith completed work on the quasi-thins. Between 1965 and 1975, a category believed only to contain five objects named for Mathieu was expanded by twenty one additional objects as part of this project, though some believe that a structure named for Jacques Tits should be considered a 27th member of that category. This project required hundreds of articles to write up a theorem categorizing structures as cyclic of prime order, alternating of degree five or above, Lie (LEE)-type, or sporadic. For 10 points, name this project whose result was the sorting of all of a basic algebraic structure into one of four categories.
tossups.answer: the classification of finite simple groups [prompt on incomplete answer; accept answers indicating the classification of groups that are finite and simple]
tossups.answer_formatted: the classification of finite simple groups [prompt on incomplete answer; accept answers indicating the classification of groups that are finite and simple]
acceptable: the classification of finite simple groups
answers indicating the classification of groups that are finite and simple

tossups.question: Sandie Byrne analyzed the poem “Suttee” as a rewriting of Southwell’s Christmas poem “The Burning Babe” with this figure in place of the Christ child. In a poem addressed to this figure, the 25 year-old speaker claims to be “dumbfounded afresh by [his] ignorance of the simplest things” after buying a peach outside Charing Cross station. This figure is “gold-jacketed, solid silver, nickel-tipped” in a poem in which the speaker notes that “your real target hid behind me.” This person, who is compared to a bullet in the poem “The Shot”, has a Veronica Lake bang in a poem that describes the author’s first glimpse of a picture of this woman and her fellow “Fulbright Scholars” at Cambridge. The poem “The Blue Flannel Suit” describes the clothes this woman wore on her first day back teaching at Smith College, her alma mater. For 10 points, name this addressee of Ted Hughes’ book Birthday Letters.

On Christmas, this saint had a conversion experience after her father said “Well, fortunately, this will be the last year!” in reference to a custom of placing presents inside her shoes. In 2015, this saint’s parents became the first married couple to be canonized together. This saint noted that rich people didn’t need to climb stairs because they had elevators, before observing that she was “too tiny to climb the steep staircase of perfection” while describing her doctrine known as the Little Way. This saint wrote that she believed she was hearing her own story when her father Louis explained the care with which God had nurtured the roots of a white flower. Her autobiography The Story of a Soul describes her development as a Discalced Carmelite nun. For 10 points, name this French woman, known as the Little Flower, a saint who hailed from the commune of Lisieux.
tossups.answer: Thérèse of Lisieux [or Marie François-Thérèse Martin]

tossups.question: The night after a president was assassinated, 18 university students who supported this conflict were strangled to death with piano wire. Official government reports state that 124 of the 150 citizens massacred t at the Woki Debra and Agi Sogdo during this conflict villages were killed by “stray bullets”. This war’s rebels were repeatedly crushed at battles like the Siege of Barentu and Massawa due to European intervention. The tide turned in this war after Mesfin Hagos ignored a command to retreat to Nakfa, instead liberating the town of Afabet. This conflict is called Gedli in the Tigrinya language. It resulted in the creation of a country that is still led by Isaias Afwerki, a president whose policy of indefinite conscription remains unpopular. This conflict, like the Ethiopian Civil War, ended with the overthrow of the Derg. For 10 points, name this war which established a national capital at Asmara.
tossups.answer: War of Eritrean Independence [or Eritrean War of Independence; accept equivalents; generously prompt on Ethiopian Civil War]
tossups.answer_formatted: War of Eritrean Independence [or Eritrean War of Independence; accept equivalents; generously prompt on Ethiopian Civil War]

tossups.question: This work formed the basis of a sound installation that Janet Cardiff exhibited in the Fuentidueña Chapel. It’s not by George Crumb, Istvan Marta, Shostakovich, or Ives, but the Kronos Quartet recorded this work for their album Black Angels. The length of this work may be a play on the total value, in gematria, of the name “Judith” and the name of this work’s composer, both of which equal 69. The Egerton and Gresham manuscripts are the principal sources of this work, whose structure may have been inspired by the architecture of Nonsuch Palace. Peter Gregson used multitracking to use a single cello to perform this work, which was likely commissioned by the Duke of Norfolk to rival Alessandro Striggio’s Ecce Beatam Lucem, which had a similar scale. This piece passes its melody in a horseshoe shape around eight five-voice choirs. For 10 points, name this 40-part motet by Thomas Tallis.
tossups.answer: Spem in Alium [or Spem in alium nunquam habui]
tossups.answer_formatted: Spem in Alium [or Spem in alium nunquam habui]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about difficult scripts from around the world, for 10 points each.
answers: Nsibidi [or nsibiri or nchibiddi or nchibiddy]
parts: Cuneiform was deciphered thanks to the discovery of this inscription on a mountainside in Iran, which includes a life sized bas-relief of Darius the Great holding a bow. It includes text in Old Persian, Elamite, and Babylonian.
This object recovered from a Minoan palace in 1908 by Luigi Pernier contains an undeciphered script spiralled along both sides. The language on this object is neither Linear A nor Linear B.

First reported by T.D. Maxwell in 1904, this system of symbols indigenous to southeastern Nigeria is used by members of the Ekpe leopard secret society. It might be logographic, it might be ideographic—no one really knows!

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the history of using computer models in economics, for 10 points each:
answers: portfolios [or stock portfolios or investment portfolios, prompt on stocks or bonds]
parts: This thinker’s Wharton forecasting model uses over a thousand simultaneously solved equations to model the U.S. economy. He led Project LINK, which integrated various countries’ macroeconomic models.
At the RAND Corporation, Herb Karr and this economist developed SIMSCRIPT for writing discrete-event simulations. He also developed the critical line algorithm for mean-variance analysis.

Markowitz also worked on optimizing these things, for which he introduced the idea of the efficient frontier, a set of these investment collections which have the highest return for their level of risk. Diversification of these things reduces risk.
answers_formatted: portfolios [or stock portfolios or investment portfolios, prompt on stocks or bonds]

bonuses.leadin: An essay by David Herlihy “reconsiders” this question, and answers it mostly in the negative by counting the number of lives entered into the Bibliotheca, a catalogue of saints. For 10 points each:
answers: Andreas Capellanus [or Andrew the Chaplain; prompt on Andrew or Andreas]
parts: Give this title question of an essay by Joan Kelly. It answers the title question in the negatory by noting how the title time period turned “noblewomen” into chaste “aesthetic objects” dependent on her prince and husband.
Kelly uses the example of declining women’s participation in the writings on the “courtly” type of this concept to argue that women lost much intellectual power and freedom during the Renaissance.
This author’s The Art of Courtly Love is used to analyze men’s attitudes towards women in the essay. One of his “rules of love” is “Marriage is no excuse for not loving”.
answers_formatted: Andreas Capellanus [or Andrew the Chaplain; prompt on Andrew or Andreas]

bonuses.leadin: In this formalism, the shift and lapse functions are used to choose convenient gauges. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this framework within general relativity, which considers a spacetime foliated into three-dimensional spacelike slices labeled by their time coordinates, and writes the equations of motion in the form of Hamilton's equations on this spacetime.
Most equations in the ADM formalism use the notation named for this physicist where any indices presented are assumed to be summed over. This physicist also names the field equations central to GR.

The Einstein field equations can be derived by finding stationary points of this quantity, which equals one over 16 pi G times the integral over the whole spacetime of the Ricci scalar times the square root of minus the determinant of the metric.

bonuses.leadin: This author wrote about Georg Falkner, a dramatist who is seduced by Vivianne, and eventually suffers from a stroke out of guilt for having an affair, in his novel Merlin. For 10 points each:
answers: Paul von Heyse [or Paul Johann Ludwig von Heyse]
parts: Name this author who, in the preface to his 24-volume German Novellas argued that novellas should have a strong "silhouette" or one-sentence summary, which is now known as the "falcon theory" of literature.

Heyse's falcon theory is named after a "silhouette" involving a "man who gives up his falcon for a young lady", a summary of one of the tales in this medieval collection narrated by ten Florentines waiting out the Black Death.
Heyse's theory of the novella was influential on this author's novella Brigitta. Milan Kundera's The Curtain praises this author's Indian Summer for depicting the "significance of bureaucracy".
answers_formatted: Paul von Heyse [or Paul Johann Ludwig von Heyse]

bonuses.leadin: It is debated if the title Biblical scene shown in this painting’s upper right is being reflected through a mirror or if it is a painting-within-a-painting. For 10 points each:
answers: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary [accept equivalents mentioning Jesus in the House of Martha and Mary]
hierarchy of genres [accept any answers indicating that genres are ordered]
parts: Name this painting by Diego Velazquez, most of which depicts two elderly women making aioli. It was inspired by the bodegon genre of paintings.

This group of Flemish artists working in Rome often painted bodegon still-lifes. These artists often depicted soldiers, children, and urinating animals in their genre-scenes and took their name from Pieter van Lear’s nickname, who was called “The Ugly Puppet”.
Bodegon still-lifes, and still-lifes in general, were at the bottom of this list articulated by the Academie Royale, whereas history and mythology scenes are at the top.
answers_formatted: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary [accept equivalents mentioning Jesus in the House of Martha and Mary]
hierarchy of genres [accept any answers indicating that genres are ordered]
acceptable: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary
equivalents mentioning Jesus in the House of Martha and Mary
any answers indicating that genres are ordered

bonuses.leadin: In general, elastomers tend to have low values of Young's modulus and of this other quantity. For 10 points each:
answers: glass transition temperature [or T sub g]
parts: Name this quantity. Like melting point, it is typically measured for an elastomer by performing differential scanning calorimetry.
A classic elastomer is natural rubber, which is a polymer of this five-carbon compound. Terpenes are also comprised of multiple units of this compound.
An elastomer known as the Terminator possesses this property, which can be conferred onto a material by adding microcapsules which contain the monomer and a catalyst embedded in an epoxy resin.

bonuses.leadin: Five modern plays from this genre, including The Damask Drum and Lady Aoi were written by Yukio Mishima. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this form of elaborate Japanese drama, characterized by the usage of masks often to represent supernatural characters. A treatise on the “style of” this drama was written by Zeami.

Yukio Mishima’s Five Modern Noh Dramas have been translated into English by this scholar, who popularized the plays of Chikamatsu in the west. He also wrote a four-volume study of Japanese literature.

Keene claims that one of the most significant developments in noh drama is this technique, in which plot exposition would occur while characters are walking and talking. Many of Chikamatsu’s plays, such as The Love Suicides at Amijima began by using this technique.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about historical figures in late 19<sup>th</sup> century America and their literary output, for 10 points each.
answers: George Bickley [or George Washington Lafayette Bickley; or George W.L. Bickley]
parts: This Indiana-born doctor who styled himself “General” founded the Knights of the Golden Circle by setting up its first “castle” in Cincinnati. He did so after the failure of his Manifest Destiny-promoting novel Adalaska.

This man introduced us to the heroic boatman Jim Bludso, who had one wife in Mississippi and another in Illinois, in his Pike County Ballads. He also worked with Lord Pauncefote on a 1901 treaty which renounced the Clayton-Bulwer Treaty.

While commanding the Freedmen’s Bureau in Greenville, South Carolina after the Civil War, this man wrote an article for The Nation entitled “The Great American Novel,” claiming that American society was changing too rapidly to be understood as a whole.
answers_formatted: George Bickley [or George Washington Lafayette Bickley; or George W.L. Bickley]

bonuses.leadin: This thinker argued that the best literature inculcates worthy lives in their readers as part of a theory of “humanics”, and that the best films spring from a single “ideology” according to the “seed” theory of cinema. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this filmmaker who wrote the beloved text On the Art of the Cinema. The theories in that book may have inspired his films Sea of Blood and The Flower Girl, both of which are credited to this father.

Kim Jong-Il was a fan of all the James Bond films, except for this one, which he considered to be blasphemous and non-canon. This final Pierce Brosnan Bond film opens with Bond being “saved by the bell” at the DMZ.

On the Art of the Cinema also inspired the creation of Unsung Heroes, a film that illustrated this movement of Kim Il-Sung, which provided economic and moral incentives for labor. It is named for a horse.

bonuses.leadin: The Canadian Traveller Problem must be solved using an algorithm of this type. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this type of algorithm that does not have access to the entire input, and therefore must solve the problem given the input one piece at a time.

This simple quadratic sorting algorithm is one of the best-known examples of an online algorithm. In it, each element in the list is sequentially selected, then placed in the proper position to form a sorted list.

Sleator and Tarjan introduced the use of this technique on the list update problem to analyze the efficiency of online algorithms. It essentially calculates the ratio of the work done by an online algorithm to its offline counterpart.

bonuses.leadin: According to Ebbo, the three parts of this deity represent the heavens, earth, and underworld. For 10 points each:
answers: Triglav [or Trihlav or Tryglaw or Troglav or Trzyglow]
Book of Veles [or Vlesbook or Isenbeck’s Planks]
parts: Name this Slavic deity who is often depicted with blindfolds over his three heads, so that he cannot see the sins of his people. His temples were found near high mountains, including the highest peak in Slovenia, which shares his name.
Another Slavic Earth god is this one, who controlled thunder and lightning and was part of a trinity with Svarog and Dazhbog. Several amulets have been discovered in the shape of his axe.

Triglav and Perun both appear in this work which was allegedly discovered on wooden planks in the early 20th century by a lieutenant in the White Russian Army. It’s probably a forgery due to its use of inconsistent language.

bonuses.leadin: At the end of a letter, this person is asked to “open your life wide, and take me in forever.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mysterious addressee of three unsent letters that survive in draft form. Scholars have posited Reverend Charles Wadsworth, Samuel Bowles, and God, among others, as possible identities for this figure.
Letters to the Master were written, probably between 1858 and 1861, by this poet, who filled them with her characteristic dashes and non-standard capitalizations.

In the Master letters, Dickinson refers to herself with this floral nickname. One of Dickinson’s poems asks “Great Caesar! condescend [this flower] to receive,” and, in “In lands I never saw—they say,” this flower dances at the foot of the “Immortal Alps.”

bonuses.leadin: The Vanuatuan creole word Bislama refers to this good’s French name, originally spoken by divers of Oceania who extracted this good. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this marine animal, which during the Qing Dynasty, was exported from Australia in the trepang trade. It was shipped from the port of Makassar to markets in Southern China.

The endpoint of the Burke and Wills Expedition was this massive gulf that indents the northern coast of Australia. This gulf west of Cape York Peninsula was the site of origin of the sea cucumber trade.

These Aboriginal people who inhabit Arnhem Land in the Northern Territory were the primary Australian participants in the trepang trade. The Caledon Bay Crisis was caused when members of this indigenous group attacked Japanese traders in 1932, provoking a harsh colonial reprisal.

bonuses.leadin: The second of this musical work’s three movements is itself subdivided into three further movements: “Through the Streets and Roads,” “The Perfumes of the Night,” and “The Morning of a Festival Day.” For 10 points each:
answers: Images pour orchestre [or Images for orchestra; accept Images Book 3 or Set 3 or Third Set; prompt on Images by asking “for what instrumentation?”]
parts: Name this work whose three-part second movement is titled “Iberia.” André Caplet may or may not have had a hand in its first movement, “Gigues.”

Debussy placed the instruction enchaînez at the end of the “Perfumes” section of “Iberia.” Enchaînez is the French equivalent of this Italian word that indicates two movements should not be separated by a pause.

Claude Debussy’s first book of Images, for solo piano, includes an “Homage to” this earlier French composer and draws its melody from this man’s opera Castor et Pollux, which includes the aria “Sejour de l’eternelle paix.”
answers_formatted: Images pour orchestre [or Images for orchestra; accept Images Book 3 or Set 3 or Third Set; prompt on Images by asking “for what instrumentation?”]

bonuses.leadin: Eyewitnesses at this event claimed that Hugh Birley led drunk members of the Manchester and Salford Yeomanry into a crowd. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1819 event, which took place in a namesake field in Manchester. Carnage here immediately resulted in passage of the Six Acts by the demand of Lord Sidmouth.

During the Peterloo Massacre, and earlier at Spa Fields, the crowd was addressed by this noted orator. This genius later advocated “radical breakfast powder,” a mix of roasted grains as a tax-free substitute for coffee and tea.

Henry Hunt and his friends may have tried to revive this secret Irish agrarian society which fought for land reform in a series of revolts from 1761 to 1765. A namesake act passed in 1765 by the Irish parliament curtailed this group.

bonuses.leadin: This drug was shown to be superior to clopidogrel in reducing the rate of mortality in patients with acute coronary syndrome in the 2009 PLATO study. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this drug. Like clopidogrel and prasugrel, it’s an anti∙platelet agent which prevents platelet aggregation by targeting the P2Y12 receptor.

Among the patients in the PLATO trial were those with an elevation in this segment of an electrocardiogram. Its elevation is often associated with heart attack, and it represents the time between depolarization and repolarization of the ventricle.
Other standard treatments for acute coronary syndrome include this painkilling NSAID derived from a secretion of the willow tree.

bonuses.leadin: In May 2017, the construction of the Art Mill project in this city was awarded to the firm ELEMENTAL, led by Alejandro Aravena. For 10 points each:
answers: I. M. Pei [or Ieoh Ming Pei]
parts: Name this city. Norman Foster’s and Zaha Hadid’s firms were chosen to design the Lusail Stadium and a hotel in Lusail respectively, both of which will be built just north of this city.

Doha is home to this museum, which was built off an artificial peninsula and inspired by the dhow ships of a nearby harbor. This museum appears to be a solid mass of stone floating on water, when walking toward it.
This now 100-year old architect agreed to design the Museum of Islamic Art only if he was allowed to work with the same team that helped him install a glass pyramid at the Louvre.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, name these British authors renowned for writing works of fiction in multiple languages.
answers: Christine Brooke-Rose [or Christine Frances Evelyn Brooke-Rose]
James Joyce [or James Augustine Aloysius Joyce]
parts: This author wrote his novels such as Watt and Murphy in English, then translated them into French.

Characters from the fiction of Goethe, Flaubert, and Pynchon speak their native tongue and converge in a San Francisco Hilton Hotel in this author’s multilingual novel Textermination. A sentient pebble overdoses on caesium and believes itself to be Lady Macbeth in this author’s Xorandor.

This author’s last novel has a story about Burrus and Caseous, which may be an allegory of dairy production in the Irish Free State. That novel by him has a first sentence mentioning “a commodius vicus of recirculation”.

bonuses.leadin: In the Critique of Pure Reason, Immanuel Kant claims that these concepts “can be understood only in a negative sense” since we do not have a “special”, “intellectual”, mode of intuition. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these things that exist outside of the realm of sense and perception. These Greek-named concepts are often identified with things-in-themselves.

Noumena are contrasted with these things in the Critique of Pure Reason. Where noumena are those things that cannot be reached by sensible intuition, these things are everything that our sensible intuition works with.

This philosopher’s “humility” argument objects to Kant’s Transcendental Idealism on the grounds that it is impossible for humans to sustain belief in the unknowability of noumena. once you are there. He coined the term “nihilism” in a letter he wrote during the Atheism dispute.
